questions.text: An infant presents with vomiting after feeding. A Benedict’s test was performed and returned positive for a non-glucose substance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Galactosemia due to GAL-1-P uridyl transferase enzyme deficiency
Hereditary fructose intolerance due to aldolase B deficiency
Galactosemia due to galactokinase enzyme deficiency

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Galactosemia due to GAL-1-P uridyl transferase enzyme deficiency:

  • This is the most likely diagnosis, given the presentation of vomiting after feeding and a positive Benedict’s test for a non-glucose substance, consistent with the presence of galactose in the urine.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hereditary fructose intolerance due to aldolase B deficiency:

  • Hereditary fructose intolerance results from a deficiency in aldolase B, leading to the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate after ingestion of fructose, sucrose, or sorbitol. Symptoms include vomiting, hypoglycemia, and liver damage. The Benedict’s test would show a positive result for fructose, but this condition typically presents after the introduction of fructose-containing foods, not in the newborn period.

Option C - Glucose-6-Phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency:

  • G6PD deficiency leads to hemolytic anemia, particularly after exposure to certain triggers like infections or certain foods/drugs. This condition does not typically cause a positive Benedict’s test for a non-glucose substance, nor does it present with vomiting after feeding.

Option D - Galactosemia due to galactokinase enzyme deficiency:

  • This milder form of galactosemia results from a deficiency in galactokinase, leading to the accumulation of galactose, which can cause cataracts. However, it usually does not cause severe systemic symptoms like those seen in GAL-1-P uridyl transferase deficiency, and the Benedict’s test would still be positive for galactose.

questions.text: A floppy infant presents with hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and an X-ray showing cardiomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pompe disease

 

Explanation:

 

Pompe disease is a glycogen storage disorder (Type II) caused by a deficiency of acid alpha-glucosidase (acid maltase). It leads to the accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes, primarily affecting cardiac and skeletal muscle.
 

Clinical features include:

  • Floppy infant with profound hypotonia ("floppy baby")

  • Cardiomegaly due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

  • Hepatomegaly from glycogen accumulation

  • Respiratory distress and feeding difficulties
    The combination of hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and cardiomegaly on X-ray fits classic infantile Pompe disease.

 

Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) (Option B): TGA is a cyanotic congenital heart defect with discordant ventriculoarterial connections. Presents with cyanosis, not hypotonia or hepatomegaly. Cardiomegaly may be present, but hepatomegaly and hypotonia are not typical.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) (Option C): TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart disease with right ventricular outflow obstruction, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and RV hypertrophy. Presents with cyanosis and "tet spells." Hypotonia and hepatomegaly are not usual features.

Ebstein's anomaly (Option D): A congenital malformation of the tricuspid valve causing atrialization of the right ventricle. Presents with cyanosis, heart failure signs, but does not typically cause hypotonia or hepatomegaly in infancy.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with pain, redness, and swelling around his great toe. His serum uric acid level is 9.4 mg/dL. His mother also mentions that he frequently bites his lips and has symptoms of spasticity and dystonia. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations, such as combination of hyperuricemia (leading to gout-like symptoms), neurological manifestations including dystonia and spasticity, and self-mutilating behavior such as lip-biting indicate Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.
  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, an X-linked recessive disorder, is caused by a deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), which results in impaired purine metabolism.

Pathophysiology:

  • HGPRT deficiency leads to:
    • Accumulation of purine metabolites
    • Excessive uric acid production
    • Neurological complications (dystonia and spasticity)

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome

Cause

Deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT)

Inheritance

X-linked recessive

Variants
  • Classic Lesch-Nyhan syndrome: Undetectable HPRT levels.
  • Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome: Partial HPRT deficiency with variable neurological dysfunction.

Clinical Features
  • Self-injurious behaviour: Biting lips, fingers, tongue; begins with tooth eruption.
  • Cognitive impairment: Intellectual disability ranging from mild to severe.
  • Movement disorder: Starts with hypotonia, progresses to dystonia, choreoathetosis, oromandibular dystonia, and inspiratory stridor.
  • Oculomotor apraxia: Difficulty controlling eye movements.
  • Dysarthric speech: Difficulty speaking clearly.

Complications
  • Hyperuricemia: Causes gout and kidney stones.
  • Neurological symptoms: Abnormalities in the dopamine system, reduced dopamine transporters.

Treatment
  • Allopurinol: Reduces uric acid levels and manages hyperuricemia.
  • Symptom management: Controls movement disorders and self-injurious behaviours.

Incorrect Options:

Cystathionine beta-synthase (Option A): This enzyme is involved in homocysteine metabolism, and its deficiency would lead to homocystinuria with manifestations like lens dislocation, skeletal abnormalities, and thromboembolism. It does not cause hyperuricemia or self-mutilating behavior.

Dihydrothymidine oxidase (Option B): This enzyme is involved in pyrimidine metabolism, and its deficiency would not cause elevated uric acid levels or neurological symptoms seen in this case.

Xanthine oxidase (Option D): Deficiency of this enzyme causes xanthinuria, characterized by low uric acid levels, not elevation as seen in this case. Its manifestations include abdominal pain, recurrent UTI, hematuria & muscle cramping.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child immediately cries after breastfeeding, followed by vomiting and diarrhea. Which enzyme deficiency might be responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Galactose-1-Phosphate Uridyl Transferase

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate Galactosemia, a disorder caused by Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT) deficiency. The immediate symptoms after breast milk ingestion, including crying, vomiting, and diarrhea, are hallmark features of this condition.

Galactosemia

Enzyme Deficiency
  • Galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase (GALT) - Classical type
  • Galactokinase - benign disease with only oil drop cataract.
  • Epimerase - SNHL + symptoms of classical type

(Low galactose-based diet can be given, which is contraindicated in the classical type)

Pathophysiology
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate (toxic causing jaundice, and liver damage)
  • Inability to metabolize galactose from milk
  • Damage to liver, kidney, and brain

Clinical Features
  • Hepatic: Jaundice, hepatomegaly
  • GI: Vomiting, diarrhea, failure to thrive
  • CNS: Seizures, intellectual disability
  • Eyes: Oil drop cataracts
  • Increased risk of E. coli sepsis

Diagnosis
  • Reducing substance in urine (positive) (Positive Benedict test but negative glucose oxidase test)
  • Direct enzyme (GALT) assay
  • Genetic testing (Perinatal diagnosis is possible)

Management
  • Lactose-free diet
  • Breast Milk contraindicated
  • Soy-based or elemental formulas
  • Calcium supplementation

Incorrect Options:

Aldolase B (Option A): This enzyme deficiency results in hereditary fructose intolerance, causing symptoms after fructose ingestion rather than milk consumption. The presenting symptoms would be triggered by fruits and sweet foods, not breast milk.

Phenylalanine Hydroxylase (Option B): Deficiency of this enzyme causes phenylketonuria (PKU), presenting with developmental delay and neurological symptoms rather than acute post-feeding distress. PKU symptoms are not immediately related to breast milk ingestion.

Glucocerebrosidase (Option D): This enzyme deficiency leads to Gaucher disease, characterized by hepatosplenomegaly, bone problems, and hematological abnormalities. It does not cause acute gastrointestinal symptoms after milk ingestion.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency can result in seizures in newborns?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pyridoxine

Explanation:

  • Deficiency of pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) can lead to refractory seizures in neonates and infants. Pyridoxine is essential for the proper functioning of the nervous system, and its deficiency can disrupt normal brain development and function, leading to seizures in newborns.

 

Deficiency of thiamine (Vitamin B1) (Option B) can result in a condition called beriberi, which primarily affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems but does not typically cause neonatal seizures.

Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) (Option C) is necessary for energy production and the metabolism of fats, carbohydrates, and proteins. While riboflavin deficiency can lead to various symptoms, including skin and eye abnormalities, it is not typically associated with neonatal seizures.

Pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5) (Option D) is involved in the synthesis of coenzyme A, which is essential for energy metabolism. Deficiency of pantothenic acid is not associated with neonatal seizures.

 

Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6):

  • RDA: 0.1-0.3 mg/day
  • Dietary Sources: Banana, wheat germ, rice, sunflower seeds, fish, poultry.

 

Pyridoxine (B6) deficiency

Cause

High protein intake.

Certain medications (eg. Isoniazid)

Oral contraceptives.

Dialysis.

Clinical features:

Infants: Irritability, seizures, vomiting, failure to thrive.

Adults: Peripheral neuritis, cheilosis, glossitis, seborrheic dermatitis, anemia.

Dependency Syndromes: Pyridoxine-dependent epilepsy, Vitamin B6-responsive anemia.

Diagnosis:

Low AST/ALT, high urinary xanthurenic acid, EEG response to pyridoxine.

Treatment:

Convulsions: 100 mg pyridoxine IM/IV, then oral intake.

Dependency: 2-10 mg IM or 10-100 mg orally daily.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with hepatosplenomegaly and cherry-red spots on the retina. The child exhibits a normal startle reflex but shows developmental regression. Based on these clinical features, which of the following enzymes is deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option b) Sphingomyelinase

Explanation

  • Hexosaminidase A (Deficient in Tay-Sachs disease):(Option A ruled out)
    • Features: Cherry-red spot, developmental regression, exaggerated startle reflex (hyperacusis), progressive neurodegeneration, no hepatosplenomegaly.
    • Fit with case: The presence of hepatosplenomegaly and normal startle reflex rules out classic Tay-Sachs.
  • Sphingomyelinase (Deficient in Niemann-Pick disease Types A and B):(Option B)
    • Features: Hepatosplenomegaly, developmental regression (especially in Type A), cherry-red spots (in Type A), interstitial lung disease, foam cells in bone marrow. The startle reflex is typically normal or not exaggerated.
    • Fit with case: This aligns very well with all the described symptoms: hepatosplenomegaly, cherry-red spots, developmental regression, and a normal startle reflex. Niemann-Pick Type A is the severe neurovisceral form.
  • Glucocerebrosidase (Deficient in Gaucher disease):(Option C ruled out)
    • Features: Hepatosplenomegaly, bone crises, pancytopenia, varying neurological involvement (Type 2 has severe neurodegeneration, Type 1 is non-neuropathic, Type 3 has progressive neurological features). Cherry-red spots are rare or absent.
    • Fit with case: The presence of cherry-red spots makes Gaucher disease less likely.
  • Arylsulfatase A (Deficient in Metachromatic Leukodystrophy):(Option D ruled out)
    • Features: Progressive demyelination leading to neurological symptoms (ataxia, spasticity, regression), peripheral neuropathy. Hepatosplenomegaly and cherry-red spots are typically absent.
    • Fit with case: This does not fit the hepatosplenomegaly or cherry-red spot findings.

questions.text: A child presents with developmental delay and coarse facial features. Enzyme assay reveals a deficiency of α-L-iduronidase. Which of the following substances is most likely to accumulate in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Dermatan sulfate + Heparan sulfate

  • α-L-iduronidase deficiency → Hurler syndrome (Mucopolysaccharidosis type I). This enzyme is required to degrade dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate. Deficiency → accumulation of both in lysosomes → progressive multisystem disease.
  • Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by α-L-iduronidase deficiency. This enzyme normally cleaves terminal iduronic acid residues in dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate. Failure to degrade these glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) → lysosomal storage in multiple tissues.

Clinical features:

  • developmental delay, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, corneal clouding, joint stiffness, skeletal abnormalities.
  • Progressive neurodegeneration occurs due to GAG accumulation in the CNS.

MPS Type

Disease Name

Enzyme Deficiency

Accumulating GAG(s)

MPS I

Hurler syndrome

α-L-iduronidase

Dermatan sulfate, Heparan sulfate

MPS II

Hunter syndrome

Iduronate sulfatase

Dermatan sulfate, Heparan sulfate

MPS III

Sanfilippo syndrome

Multiple enzyme defects

Heparan sulfate

MPS IV

Morquio syndrome

Galactosamine-6-sulfatase or β-galactosidase

Keratan sulfate

MPS VI

Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome

Arylsulfatase B

Dermatan sulfate

MPS VII

Sly syndrome

β-glucuronidase

Dermatan sulfate, Heparan sulfate, Chondroitin sulfate

Management:

  • ↑ urinary excretion of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate; confirmed by enzyme assay.
  • Management is supportive ± enzyme replacement therapy (laronidase).

Dermatan sulfate + Chondroitin sulfate (Option A)- Chondroitin sulfate is not a substrate for α-L-iduronidase; it’s degraded by other enzymes.

Only Dermatan sulfate (Option B) is incorrect because α-L-iduronidase also acts on heparan sulfate; both accumulate.

Heparan sulfate + Chondroitin sulfate (Option D)- Chondroitin sulfate is not involved in Hurler syndrome; dermatan sulfate is the correct partner with heparan sulfate.

questions.text: Menke's disease is a metabolic defect in the process of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Copper:

  • Menke's disease is a rare X-linked recessive disorder characterized by impaired copper absorption and transport.
  • It is caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene that regulates the metabolism of copper in the body.
  • As a result, copper metabolism is disrupted, leading to copper deficiency and subsequent neurological and developmental abnormalities.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 10-year-old child who is brought to the clinic with developmental delay and extrapyramidal symptoms and is found to have a lens dislocation towards the inferonasal area during further examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Homocystinuria:

  • Homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by impaired metabolism of the amino acid methionine.
  • It is caused by deficiencies in enzymes involved in the conversion of methionine to cysteine.
  • The dislocation of the lens (ectopia lentis) is a characteristic feature of homocystinuria.
  • Additionally, patients may present with developmental delays, intellectual disability, and extrapyramidal symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Marfan syndrome:

  • Marfan syndrome is a connective tissue disorder caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene.
  • While it can also present with ectopia lentis, it is not associated with the developmental delays and extrapyramidal symptoms.

Option C - Alkaptonuria:

  • Alkaptonuria is a metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation of homogentisic acid.
  • It does not typically present with dislocated lenses or extrapyramidal symptoms.

Option D - Wilson disease:

  • Wilson disease is a disorder of copper metabolism characterized by the accumulation of copper in various organs, particularly the liver and brain.
  • It does not typically present with ectopia lentis or developmental delays.
